ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Working with Mark Ashton: check. Travel to Brazil: check. Getting an amazing immersion into on-the-ground conservation challenges: check. Yep, a great class.
Class got off to a slow start, but the pace was better a couple weeks before we left for the trip
The trip, obviously. But also the fact that the end product is designed to be a publishable paper.
The trip to Brazil.

Field work, incredible planning and organization in Brazil by Jeff, allowed us to accomplish many research objectives in a week. Mark was incredibly generous and supportive through the entire process, although much of the work we had to do even fell outside of his purview. The best part were the two weeks we spent in Brazil seeing a beautiful place, meeting amazing people, and seeing a real, potent conservation issue on the ground. No better way of learning, and it was incredibly eye-opening and humbling learning from some amazing classmates.Mark also structures the class well, forcing us to do a lot of preliminary background work, leading up to the trip, and then keeps us on task for the writing and analysis part. Somehow it works!
The opportunity to integrate a wide range of disciplines in a real life setting - i.e. something approximating a real work experience.
Going to Bahia and learning in the field with Mark

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Mark needs to have an outline for the semester at the beginning of the class, with firm details and all. He should assign the different subjects for the pre-trip booklet on the first or second week of class and have people start putting that book together in the first three weeks of class. And have people build a lit review for their subject with an annotated bibliography in advance of the course. As for how it ran down in Brazil, I have few changes to suggest. It was helpful when Mark suggested we break into smaller groups--I think sometimes we didn't know what the process was and take enough agency to do that ourselves (like at the IFV nursery), but I appreciated when Mark split the group up--we learned much more in small groups. I'd also suggest limiting future trips to people speaking the language. I think you'll get a better work product.

Have a project with more focused objectives going in, and a client who is more specific and organized about what they want. We were definitely grasping at air for much of the time trying to figure out what would the best way to focus our efforts.
Can't think of any. Great course!

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Excellent: Jeff Stoike was amazing. Mark was busy this semester so not as engaged as he might be, but the reality is he has an open door policy, so if you seek him out, he's always available. My classmates tended not to, though, and didn't get quite enough coaching in the class at times; still, I blame them for not actively seeking out the support they wanted.

Excellent availability, although brief meetings at times. Of course in Brazil, both Mark and Jeff were available 100% to support our work and offer advice, I can't suggest any improvements.Also, even though Jeff was in Brazil most of the time, he did a great job of supporting us and providing us information and contacts throughout the semester.
Both Mark and Jeff were pretty available

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Great for learning the practices of a rapid assessment.

Great culmination/capstone class for peoplewho are interested in any applied aspect of tropical forest conservation. Although realistically, work that is more qualitative and uses social science methods is the most feasible to carry out during the week of field work.

This class took a variety of topics I've worked on and applied them in a real life setting - it was one of the few class experiences at FES where I thought, "this makes sense as (part of) a future career path."
I'm interested in tropical conservation...this class was perfect

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To get field experience, which I did. I didn't feel quite as prepared as I would have liked before we left, and I think if Mark had jump-started the process with us building our pre-trip book and doing presentations in January, then moving to building our questions/target interviewee list, etc. in Feb., we would all have frontloaded some more work and have a bit more of a lit review under our belts before the trip.
To learn from Mark, and to go to Brazil.

Wanted to see a beautiful place, work on real research toward a publishable paper (which we'll be working on for a while), learn a bit more Portuguese, and just have a very memorable and valuable experience that you can only get from FES.
highly recomended. intresting subject material and location of study.
I wanted more field work within the "rapid assessments" framework, i.e. i see myself doing similar consulting work in the future

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: absolutely. thrilled with the trip.
Yes.
Yes, absolutely.
yes
yes!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
Yes.
Learned an amazing amount, yes!
yes
yes, i learned a lot and was really glad i took the course

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Good--we had a wide range of expertise. Almost too wide, though. Our school has a lot of generalists, few specialists. Would have been nice to have more specialists in the bunch, and more narrowly focused on the needs of the client. Instead, the client gets what the class has the capacity and interest to offer.
Very valuable to keep each other on task, write down information (during meetings, interviews) that you might miss, and have someone dedicated to the same objectives that you can bounce ideas off of.
always a challenge with group work but we worked well together, especially when we weren't overwhelmed by work fromother classes

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: We fundraised by applying to Carpenter-Sperry as a group, as well as pitching Dave DeFusco on a feature story about our trip, afterwards.

Try to get focused early and have very clear objectives going in. You'll have a lot of leeway in the field, but seek out help early and often. Also, study and practice the language before you go, it makes a huge difference in what you can accomplish in the field.
Take the course, do the reading, make the most of it!
